Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Electron Microprobe for Major and Trace Element Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds to acquire a modern Electron Microprobe. Electron microprobe analysis is a technique for the chemical quantification of sub-micron volumes of solid material, a basic requirement across the full range of natural and engineering sciences. The new instrument will maximize spatial and analytical precision (to 200-700 nanometers and 1-10 parts per million levels). A core regional facility is envisioned to enable cutting-edge science, new discovery opportunities, and to complement the teaching missions of institutions throughout the Rocky Mountain region. The facility will support dissertations and theses for graduate and undergraduate students, and a variety of training opportunities will be offered including a new course on analytical techniques and one-day workshops on using the instrument.

Identification of the chemical compositions and fine spatial heterogeneities in natural materials (e.g. rocks, minerals, fossils, soil) is crucial for understanding formation processes and material properties, whereas engineered synthetic materials require characterization for technology design and quality control. Minor and trace element compositions can enable determination of the origin of a variety of natural Earth. These data can help determine the processes associated with the formation of strategic ore deposits, and to understand processes affecting potential microbial life forms on the deep seafloor and in other planetary environments. Minor and trace element variation can dramatically alter the properties of metals, ceramics, carbides and other synthetic materials. Newly developed techniques allow electron microprobe analysis of thin films for both layer thickness and composition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electron microprobe (EMP) analysis is a technique for the chemical quantification of (sub-)micron volumes of solid material, a basic requirement across the full range of natural and engineering sciences. For 30 years, the EMP laboratory in the University of Colorado's (CU) Department of Geological Sciences has provided this capability for in situ non-destructive major element analysis of natural and synthetic materials. The purpose of this project was to replace the original instrument (installed in 1988), which was seriously aging and severely limited for precise and accurate analysis of minor elements (<1000 ppm). The latter point is critical because 21st century advances in solid Earth and biological sciences, natural and renewable energy, materials science, and environmental studies demand significantly improved spatial resolution and trace element EMP analytical capabilities (1-100 ppm range). Many potential users with NSF funding, including all of the PIs for this project, currently do this type of research, but prior to obtaining the new instrument, had to travel to other institutions outside of the region to perform the work. The new instrument maximizes spatial and analytical precision (down to 200-700 nanometers and 1-10 ppm levels). This is a core regional facility that enables cutting-edge science, new discovery opportunities, and complements the teaching missions of institutions throughout the Rocky Mountain region. The new instrument, a 5-spectrometer JEOL JXA-8230, was delivered and installed in 2016 and is now fully functional.

 

Improved capabilities for in situ minor and trace element analysis is a logical next step for the evolution of solid-state analytical research in the Rocky Mountain region. Identification of the chemical compositions and fine spatial heterogeneities in natural materials (e.g. rocks, minerals, fossils, soil) is crucial for understanding formation processes and material properties, whereas engineered synthetic materials require characterization for technology design and quality control. For example, minor and trace element compositions can enable determination of the origin of a variety of natural Earth materials (e.g., U-Th-total Pb geochronology of rare earth element [REE] phosphates, REE patterns in minerals, trace elements in carbonate rock and fossils, provenance characterization of sediment and ancient building stone). These data can help determine the processes associated with the formation of strategic ore deposits, and to understand processes affecting potential microbial life forms on the deep seafloor and in other planetary environments. Minor and trace element variation can dramatically alter the properties of metals, ceramics, carbides and other synthetic materials. Newly developed techniques allow EMP analysis of thin films for both layer thickness and composition. However, most of these analyses were impossible to obtain with the old instrument without prohibitively large uncertainties.

 

The EMP lab at the University of Colorado is the only one hosted by an academic institution in Colorado, and it's geographic location on the eastern portal of the Rocky Mountains positions it well for hosting a multi-user facility that reinforces collaborations throughout the region. The CU facility continues to support dissertations and theses for graduate and undergraduate students, and a variety of training opportunities are offered including one-day workshops, introductory modules for undergraduate courses, and graduate level courses on analytical instrumentation. Other regional institutions also utilize the lab for teaching purposes. The University of Colorado, Geological Sciences, and the PIs are committed to enhancing diversity in STEM education, as exemplified by departmental and PI involvement in a number of programs targeting graduate and undergraduate underrepresented minority groups.
